) Informants are classiﬁed into three categories: a. Conﬁdential Informant (CI) b. Cooperating Witness (CW) c. Source of Information (SOI) (

) A Conﬁdential Informant (CI) is any individual who: a. provides useful and credible information to a special agent regarding criminal activities, and from whom a special agent expects or intends obtain additional useful and credible information regarding such in the future; b. acts at the direction of the IRS; and c. has any one of the following characteristics: • expects their identity to remain conﬁdential • faces the potential of any type of retaliation • receives payment or other compensation for future information or services; an executed MOU is required • is a federal prisoner, or • is a current or former member of the witness security program (
) If deemed necessary, a special agent or supervisor may classify an as a conﬁdential informant for any other reason not listed that would conﬁdentiality. (
) The identity of the conﬁdential informant is legally protected under the Exemption (b)(

)(D) of the FOIA provides for the protection of records or mation that can disclose the identity of a conﬁdential source. The Supreme Court has ruled that conﬁdentiality should not be applied automatically by enforcement, but on a case by case basis. Consideration may include the derstanding by the informant that the communications are conﬁdential, of retaliation, prior retaliatory acts, or dangers faced by prison informants. (

) Conﬁdentiality is not an assurance of complete anonymity or secrecy, but assurance that the IRS will not disclose the cooperation of the CI, the tion they provide, or their identity unless absolutely necessary. (
) To prevent the CI from testifying, the special agent will put forth every effort secure other evidence and witnesses in place of the CI. (
